# DSEval

<!-- badges: start -->

[![Lifecycle:
experimental](https://img.shields.io/badge/lifecycle-experimental-orange.svg)](https://lifecycle.r-lib.org/articles/stages.html#experimental)
[![CRAN
status](https://www.r-pkg.org/badges/version/DSBench)](https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=DSBench)
<!-- badges: end -->

This repository implements an adaptation of
[DSBench](https://arxiv.org/abs/2409.07703), a data science LLM
evaluation, in R using [vitals](https://vitals.tidyverse.org/).

The original benchmark contains 466 data analysis questions:

- In DSBench, each question has a multiple choice answer. This is an
  issue: very seldomly in real life do data science tasks end with a
  multiple choice answer. Also, this increases the risk of sandbagging,
  where models will realize they’re being evaluated and their behavior
  might change as a result. DSEval rephrases questions to have
  open-ended answers.
- In DSBench, the .xslx, .csv, and other source files are inlined into
  the user prompt. In DSEval, models are situated in a working directory
  where those files exist.
- File names and references are renamed to be less indicative of
  competition data science / model evaluations, also to descrease the
  risk of sandbagging.
- Rather than requiring the agent to complete the task in one fell
  swoop, the agent is allowed to ask a user questions. That “user” is
  actually a “model-in-the-middle”, instructed to generally provide a
  thumbs-up and little guidance.

> IMPORTANT
>
> This evaluation is highly experimental and much of its documentation
> is aspirational.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    DSBench/data/00000001, INTRODUCTION\nAll the inputs mentioned below are provided in the workbook for this case study. \nYou are working for a company that is planning to bid for a 20% stake in the cashflows of a biomass plant \nwhich burns wood chip to produce electricity. You have been asked to predict the cashflows of the project \nfrom 1 January 2017 until 31 December 2026, using a quarterly model, and to use your model to \nrecommend to your CEO the purchase price she should offer for the 20% stake. \nYou should assume that all invoices are settled in the same quarter they are issued, there are no \ninventory requirements and no taxes are applicable. \nWhere amounts are to be inflated they are given in 2017 prices and inflation should be applied on 1 \nJanuary of each subsequent year.  Do NOT round inflated prices to whole cents in interim calculations. \nELECTRICITY GENERATION \nThe plant is a 9MW plant; i.e. if it is running at full capacity it will produce 9MWh of electricity per hour. \nYour company’s engineers think it is reasonable to assume that the plant will usually run at 95% of its \ncapacity, 24 hours a day. \nThere are several planned shutdown periods when no electricity will be produced at all from the start of \nthe first day (at midnight) until the end of the final day (at midnight). \n\nFirst day of shutdown     Final day of shutdown\n1 June 2017               15 June 2017\n15 December 2019          3 January 2020\n5 April 2021              25 April 2021\n25 October 2023           10 November 2023\n6 May 2025                26 May 2025\n26 June 2026              5 July 2026\n\n\nSALE OF ELECTRICITY \nElectricity is sold as follows: \n• At the market price if this is between the cap price and the floor price.\nThe predictions for the market price have been provided in the workbook accompanying this \nquestion on an April -March annual timeline, and should not be inflated. \n• At the cap price if the market price is higher than the cap price.\nThe cap price is $70 per MWh, inflated at 2% per annum. \n• At the floor price if the market price is lower than the floor price.\nThe floor price is $45 per MWh, inflated at 1% per annum.\n \nYour CEO is concerned that the market price predictions for the sale of electricity may be overly optimistic.  \nShe has therefore asked you to run some of the analysis (see Questions 5, 11 and 13) as though \nelectricity were always sold at the floor price.  It will be beneficial if you develop your model in a way that \nmakes it easy to switch between modelling the electricity price as described above and modelling only the \nfloor price. \nPURCHASE OF WOOD CHIP \nIn each quarter, the project purchases exactly enough wood chip to produce the MWh output of the plant \nin that quarter. \nThe plant has two possible wood chip suppliers. The project first buys the wood chip from the supplier that \ngives them the lowest cost per MWh in that quarter, and, if necessary, tops this up with wood chip from \nthe other supplier. \nThe first supplier sells wood chip on the following terms: \n• Wood chip costs $100 per tonne, inflated at 2% per annum\n• 1 tonne of wood chip will produce 3.5 MWh of electricity\n• Up to 4,500 tonnes may be purchased per quarter\nThe second supplier sells wood chip on the following terms: \n• Wood chip costs $130 per tonne. This is a fixed price that should not be inflated\n• 1 tonne of wood chip will produce 4 MWh of electricity\n• An unlimited amount of wood chip may be purchased per quarter\nFIXED COSTS \nThe project incurs $75,000 of fixed costs per month. This amount is indexed at 1.5%. \nVALUATION \nThe company’s required rate of return for this project is 10%, and you should assume that there is no \nterminal value or disposal costs for the 20% stake at the end of the ten years. \nTo determine the purchase price your company should offer: \ni) Discount using an Excel function (or functions) that discounts on an actual/365 basis;\nii) Assume an acquisition date of 31 December 2016; and\niii) Assume that all cashflows occur at the end of the quarter in which they occur.\n \nGENERAL COMMENTS \nWhen used in the question wording, “Q1” refers to the period January to March, “Q2” to the period April to \nJune, “Q3” to the period July to September and “Q4” to the period October to December. \n \nFor Questions 6 to 17, perform your analysis assuming a 10% required rate of return. \nFor Question 18, perform your analysis assuming a 4% required rate of return. \n \nFor Questions 6 to 16, select your answer from a multiple choice list. \nFor Questions 17 to 18, you are required to type in your answer.\n\n\nQuestion 6\nHow many days is the plant operational in Q4 2023?\nA. 72\nB. 73\nC. 74\nD. 75\nE. 76\nF. 77\nG. 78\nH. 79\nI. 80

Do NOT round inflated prices to whole cents in interim calculations. \nELECTRICITY GENERATION \nThe plant is a 9MW plant; i.e. if it is running at full capacity it will produce 9MWh of electricity per hour. \nYour company’s engineers think it is reasonable to assume that the plant will usually run at 95% of its \ncapacity, 24 hours a day. \nThere are several planned shutdown periods when no electricity will be produced at all from the start of \nthe first day (at midnight) until the end of the final day (at midnight). \n\nFirst day of shutdown     Final day of shutdown\n1 June 2017               15 June 2017\n15 December 2019          3 January 2020\n5 April 2021              25 April 2021\n25 October 2023           10 November 2023\n6 May 2025                26 May 2025\n26 June 2026              5 July 2026\n\n\nSALE OF ELECTRICITY \nElectricity is sold as follows: \n• At the market price if this is between the cap price and the floor price.\nThe predictions for the market price have been provided in the workbook accompanying this \nquestion on an April -March annual timeline, and should not be inflated. \n• At the cap price if the market price is higher than the cap price.\nThe cap price is $70 per MWh, inflated at 2% per annum. \n• At the floor price if the market price is lower than the floor price.\nThe floor price is $45 per MWh, inflated at 1% per annum.\n \nYour CEO is concerned that the market price predictions for the sale of electricity may be overly optimistic.  \nShe has therefore asked you to run some of the analysis (see Questions 5, 11 and 13) as though \nelectricity were always sold at the floor price.  It will be beneficial if you develop your model in a way that \nmakes it easy to switch between modelling the electricity price as described above and modelling only the \nfloor price. \nPURCHASE OF WOOD CHIP \nIn each quarter, the project purchases exactly enough wood chip to produce the MWh output of the plant \nin that quarter. \nThe plant has two possible wood chip suppliers. The project first buys the wood chip from the supplier that \ngives them the lowest cost per MWh in that quarter, and, if necessary, tops this up with wood chip from \nthe other supplier. \nThe first supplier sells wood chip on the following terms: \n• Wood chip costs $100 per tonne, inflated at 2% per annum\n• 1 tonne of wood chip will produce 3.5 MWh of electricity\n• Up to 4,500 tonnes may be purchased per quarter\nThe second supplier sells wood chip on the following terms: \n• Wood chip costs $130 per tonne. This is a fixed price that should not be inflated\n• 1 tonne of wood chip will produce 4 MWh of electricity\n• An unlimited amount of wood chip may be purchased per quarter\nFIXED COSTS \nThe project incurs $75,000 of fixed costs per month. This amount is indexed at 1.5%. \nVALUATION \nThe company’s required rate of return for this project is 10%, and you should assume that there is no \nterminal value or disposal costs for the 20% stake at the end of the ten years. \nTo determine the purchase price your company should offer: \ni) Discount using an Excel function (or functions) that discounts on an actual/365 basis;\nii) Assume an acquisition date of 31 December 2016; and\niii) Assume that all cashflows occur at the end of the quarter in which they occur.\n \nGENERAL COMMENTS \nWhen used in the question wording, “Q1” refers to the period January to March, “Q2” to the period April to \nJune, “Q3” to the period July to September and “Q4” to the period October to December. \n \nFor Questions 6 to 17, perform your analysis assuming a 10% required rate of return. \nFor Question 18, perform your analysis assuming a 4% required rate of return. \n \nFor Questions 6 to 16, select your answer from a multiple choice list. \nFor Questions 17 to 18, you are required to type in your answer.\n\n\nQuestion 18\nWhat price should your company offer for a 20% stake in the plant in order to earn the 4% required\nrate of return based on the revenues calculated using the floor price only? Round your answer to\nthe nearest whole dollar.\nType in your answer, without any dollar signs or thousands separator.  E.g. $1,000,000 should be typed\nas 1000000.

                                      DSBench/data/00000003, INTRODUCTION\nA friend has approached you asking for help estimating the winning odds on a heavily modified variation of \na popular dice game. His version of the game works as follows: \n• \nThe player rolls 3 dice, each die has 6 sides \n• \nIf the total rolled is 3,4,5,16,17 or 18 the player loses \n• \nIf the total rolled is 7 or 11 the player wins \n• \nIf any other number is rolled, the player rolls again \n• \nRerolls work the same way as the initial roll, except that if the player rolls the same number as their \nfirst roll they win. For example if the player rolls 15-13-6-15 they would win \n \nYou quickly identify this as a statistical problem but given the complexity and the fact that you slept \nthrough most of your statistics classes at university, you decide to use a Monte Carlo simulation to \nestimate the odds.  \nWhen preparing your analysis you should assume the following: \n• \nNo more than 50 rolls are required to achieve a result \n• \n5000 outcomes are required to prepare your Monte Carlo.  \n \nFor simplicity, you could use a Data Table to run your Monte Carlo.\n\nQUESTION 1 What is the probability of the player winning the game? a) <60% b) 60%-65% c) 65%-70% d) >70%

                                                                                                                                                                                                                  DSBench/data/00000004, INTRODUCTION\nAll the inputs mentioned below are provided in the workbook for this case study. \nYou have been asked to model the revenues and costs for the operator of a waste processing plant. \nThe plant receives waste from two sources – from the authority that commissioned the plant and from third \nparties. The authority waste is split into a guaranteed tonnage amount and an additional tonnage amount. \nIf the authority tonnage received in a given period is less than the guaranteed tonnage amount, then \nrevenue is still received for the “missing” tonnage. Tonnage which is paid for but not received in this \nmanner is written off against additional tonnage in later quarters. \nThere is a subcontractor which processes the waste and charges a fee proportional to the amount of \nwaste that is incinerated. Once processed, waste is either incinerated, recycled or landfilled. The revenue \nreceived from the recycling and the cost of landfill is passed through to the operator. \nThe flowchart on the following page describes how the total waste processed in each quarter is split into \ndifferent categories. On the flowchart, the numbers in brackets next to each waste stream indicate the cost \nand revenue types which apply to that waste stream. The different revenues and costs are described in \nthe table below. \nWhere amounts are to be inflated, they are given in 2017 prices.                       DSBench/data/00000006, INTRODUCTION\nAn election has been held for the Congress in the fictional country of Excelstan.  Excelstan is a small \ncountry and is divided into 9 Districts, named after letters of the Greek alphabet.  Each District elects one \nmember to Congress.  There are 1000 voters.  Each voter is assigned a District Code based on where \nthey live.  The District Code is a number between 105 and 194 and determines what District the voter \nvotes for. \nDistrict Code | District\n105 - 114 Alpha\n115 - 124 Beta\n125 - 134 Gamma\n135 - 144 Delta\n145 - 154 Epsilon\n155 - 164 Zeta\n165 - 174 Eta\n175 - 184 Theta\n185 - 194 Iota\n \nThere are 8 political parties in Excelstan competing for seats in the Congress. \nThe parties are Red, Orange, Yellow, Green, Blue, Purple, Brown and Black. \nVoters cast their ballot by numbering 1 against their first choice.  After this, they can choose to provide \npreferences by numbering 2 against their second choice, 3 against their third choice, and so on up to 8 \nagainst their eighth choice.  Voters can choose how far down they give preferences to. In the data \nprovided, every voter has voted for either 4, 5, 6, 7 or 8 parties in preferential order. \nWhen counting votes, if a voter has not provided a preference number against a particular party, assume \nthey gave that party an 8 (i.e. they ranked any unmarked party equal last). \nEach District is counted independently of the other Districts, using only the votes from that \nDistrict. \nCOUNTING THE VOTES \nExcelstan has two different systems for counting votes to determine which party wins each District. \nCounting System 1: First Past The Post \nCounting System 2: Points Allocation (also known as ‘Eurovision style’) \n\nCOUNTING SYSTEM 1: FIRST PAST THE POST \nThe party with the most number of “1” votes wins.  If two or more parties tie for the most number of “1” \nvotes, then the winner is the party that received the most “2” votes (from the set of parties that tied for the \nmost “1” votes).  If there is still a tie, then count the “3” votes and so on until a winner is determined. \n \nCOUNTING SYSTEM 2: POINTS ALLOCATION \nParties receive points for each vote. The better the preference, the more points received. \n\nVote Preference    Points\n1                  12\n2                  10\n3                  8\n4                  6\n5                  4\n6                  2\n7                  1\n8                  0\n\n \nThe party with the highest number of points wins the District. \n \nThe workbook provided contains all of the voting data. DSBench/data/00000006, INTRODUCTION\nAn election has been held for the Congress in the fictional country of Excelstan.  Excelstan is a small \ncountry and is divided into 9 Districts, named after letters of the Greek alphabet.  Each District elects one \nmember to Congress.  There are 1000 voters.  Each voter is assigned a District Code based on where \nthey live.  The District Code is a number between 105 and 194 and determines what District the voter \nvotes for. \nDistrict Code | District\n105 - 114 Alpha\n115 - 124 Beta\n125 - 134 Gamma\n135 - 144 Delta\n145 - 154 Epsilon\n155 - 164 Zeta\n165 - 174 Eta\n175 - 184 Theta\n185 - 194 Iota\n \nThere are 8 political parties in Excelstan competing for seats in the Congress. \nThe parties are Red, Orange, Yellow, Green, Blue, Purple, Brown and Black. \nVoters cast their ballot by numbering 1 against their first choice.  After this, they can choose to provide \npreferences by numbering 2 against their second choice, 3 against their third choice, and so on up to 8 \nagainst their eighth choice.  Voters can choose how far down they give preferences to. In the data \nprovided, every voter has voted for either 4, 5, 6, 7 or 8 parties in preferential order. \nWhen counting votes, if a voter has not provided a preference number against a particular party, assume \nthey gave that party an 8 (i.e. they ranked any unmarked party equal last). \nEach District is counted independently of the other Districts, using only the votes from that \nDistrict. \nCOUNTING THE VOTES \nExcelstan has two different systems for counting votes to determine which party wins each District. \nCounting System 1: First Past The Post \nCounting System 2: Points Allocation (also known as ‘Eurovision style’) \n\nCOUNTING SYSTEM 1: FIRST PAST THE POST \nThe party with the most number of “1” votes wins.  If two or more parties tie for the most number of “1” \nvotes, then the winner is the party that received the most “2” votes (from the set of parties that tied for the \nmost “1” votes).  If there is still a tie, then count the “3” votes and so on until a winner is determined. \n \nCOUNTING SYSTEM 2: POINTS ALLOCATION \nParties receive points for each vote. The better the preference, the more points received. \n\nVote Preference    Points\n1                  12\n2                  10\n3                  8\n4                  6\n5                  4\n6                  2\n7                  1\n8                  0\n\n \nThe party with the highest number of points wins the District. \n \nThe workbook provided contains all of the voting data.  In order to answer all of the questions, you will \nneed to use the rules of each counting system below to determine the winning party or parties for each \nDistrict under each counting system. \nQuestions 17 to 19 and 26 relate to multiple Counting Systems. \nQuestions 20 to 22 relate to Counting System 1: First Past the Post \nQuestions 23 to 25 relate to Counting System 2: Points Allocation \n \n\nFor Questions 17 to 24, select your answer from a multiple choice list. \nFor Questions 25 to 26, you are required to type in your answer.\n\nQuestion 19 What was the highest number of first preferences received by the Orange party in any District?\nA. 11 B. 12 C. 13 D. 14 E. 15 F. 16 G. 17 H. 18 I. 19

If there is still a tie, then count the “3” votes and so on until a winner is determined. \n \nCOUNTING SYSTEM 2: POINTS ALLOCATION \nParties receive points for each vote. The better the preference, the more points received. \n\nVote Preference    Points\n1                  12\n2                  10\n3                  8\n4                  6\n5                  4\n6                  2\n7                  1\n8                  0\n\n \nThe party with the highest number of points wins the District. \n \nThe workbook provided contains all of the voting data.  In order to answer all of the questions, you will \nneed to use the rules of each counting system below to determine the winning party or parties for each \nDistrict under each counting system. \nQuestions 17 to 19 and 26 relate to multiple Counting Systems. \nQuestions 20 to 22 relate to Counting System 1: First Past the Post \nQuestions 23 to 25 relate to Counting System 2: Points Allocation \n \n\nFor Questions 17 to 24, select your answer from a multiple choice list. \nFor Questions 25 to 26, you are required to type in your answer.\n\nQuestion 26 Consider all of the Districts that have a different winner when First Past The Post is used compared to when Points Allocation is used. Take the first letter of each of these District names and combine those letters (in the order Alpha, Beta, Gamma, Delta, Epsilon, Zeta, Eta, Theta, Iota) to form a word. What is that word? or\nii) If solving for the Sculpted DSCR, the largest possible DSCR\nThat still allows the debt to be repaid by the Latest allowed Debt Maturity Date, without the DSCR ever \nfalling below the Sculpted DSCR value in any given quarter. \n \nFor the 3rd, 4th and 5th dot point items, Optimal values are defined as: \ni) If not provided with the Required Rate of Return, the values that maximise the Equity IRR, which\nwill then become the Required Rate of Return \nii) If provided with the Required Rate of Return, the values that maximise the Purchase Price whilst\nensuring that the Equity IRR is not less than the Required Rate of Return. \nBuild your model adhering to the included Details, and then answer the Questions. \nFurther conditions (“Requirements of a Solved Model”) are listed at the bottom of the Inputs worksheet. \nQUESTION SUMMARY \nQuestions 1 to 20 are based on the provided input scenarios. \nQuestions 21 to 23 may require you to change some of the existing user-variable input values from certain \nscenarios in order to answer. \n \nPrecision of Answers: \nIf submitting a dollar value, give your answer rounded to the nearest thousand dollar  \n(i.e. 0 decimal places when working in units of [$’000] ). Purchase Date Cash Flows \nOn the Purchase Date, the debt facility is drawn with a single drawdown and a single equity \ninvestment is made (there are no other equity investments at any time).  The sum of these two \namounts equals the Purchase Price which immediately goes to the State.  In other words, net cash \nflow for the Purchase Date is zero. \n2. Interest Calculations \nInterest is calculated on the last day of each quarter as  \n(Opening Balance in Quarter) * (Rate % p.a.) * (Days in Qtr) / 365 \nThis applies to both the interest owed on the Debt, and the interest earned / (owed) on any positive / \n(negative) cash account balance. \n3. Refinancing Calculations \nThe debt is refinanced at three points throughout the term.  The refinanced amount is the outstanding \ndebt balance immediately after principal repayment on the refinancing date. A fee is charged on the \nrefinanced amount, and this fee is capitalised into the debt balance.  For clarity, there is no fee \npayable on the fee itself.  The fee is only charged on the old balance that is being refinanced. \n4. Debt Interest Payments \nInterest owed is always paid in full at the end of each quarter for the entire life of the debt facility. \n5. Debt Principal Repayments \nDebt is repaid on the last day of each quarter, commencing on the First Debt Repayment Date, \ncontinuing every quarter until the facility is fully repaid.  All debt must be paid off on or before the \nLatest Allowed Debt Maturity Date.  The amount of each repayment must be sculpted so that the \nDSCR is constant for all quarters during the repayment term.  The only exception to this is the final \nrepayment quarter, which can have a higher DSCR.  The repayment amount in any quarter cannot \nexceed the quarterly opening balance of the facility.  Redraws are not permitted. \n6. DSCR \nThe DSCR is defined only for quarters where the principal repayment amount is not zero.  It is equal \neach quarter to the quarterly value of CFADS / (Net Interest Expense + Principal Repayments) \n7. CFADS \nCFADS (Cash Flow Available for Debt Service) is provided by the ‘Operations’ worksheet for each \nquarter.  For clarity, the definition of CFADS does not include any carryover opening balance. \nHint:  Assumptions have been set so that CFADS will be relatively smooth and healthy, and will \nalways be at least as large as Net Interest Expense * Sculpted DSCR \n8. Net Interest Expense \nDefined as: For each quarter, interest owed on Debt plus interest owed on cash account overdraft \nbalance (if any) less interest earned on cash account positive balance (if any).  \n9. Cash Flow Waterfall \nThe Cash Flow Waterfall should include only the following items: \n(1) CFADS; (2) Interest Revenue/(Overdraft Expense) on Cash Balance; (3) Interest Expense \non Debt; (4) Principal Repayments; (5) Equity Distributions \nAll cashflows are assumed to occur on the final day of each quarter. \n10. Equity Distributions \nDistributions occur on the last day of each quarter every June during the Asset life, and at the Asset \nExpiration Date.  All available cash (including the carry over opening balance) is distributed each \ndistribution date, so long as the cash balance is positive immediately prior to distributions. \n11. Equity IRR \nThe Equity IRR should be calculated using the XIRR function, and consider the cashflows to/from \nequity between the Purchase Date and the Asset Expiration Date inclusive. \n \n\nQuestion 1 \nFor Scenario 1, what is the date of the final debt repayment? There is no need to write “k” or “,000” at the end. \nIf submitting a DSCR value, give your answer to 3 decimal places \nIf submitting a percentage rate, give your answer as a percentage to 3 decimal places (e.g. 11.543%) \nIf submitting a date, give your answer rounded to the nearest day. (That’s a joke…) \n\nDETAILS \n1. Purchase Date Cash Flows \nOn the Purchase Date, the debt facility is drawn with a single drawdown and a single equity \ninvestment is made (there are no other equity investments at any time).  The sum of these two \namounts equals the Purchase Price which immediately goes to the State.  In other words, net cash \nflow for the Purchase Date is zero. \n2. Interest Calculations \nInterest is calculated on the last day of each quarter as  \n(Opening Balance in Quarter) * (Rate % p.a.) * (Days in Qtr) / 365 \nThis applies to both the interest owed on the Debt, and the interest earned / (owed) on any positive / \n(negative) cash account balance. \n3. Refinancing Calculations \nThe debt is refinanced at three points throughout the term.  The refinanced amount is the outstanding \ndebt balance immediately after principal repayment on the refinancing date. A fee is charged on the \nrefinanced amount, and this fee is capitalised into the debt balance.  For clarity, there is no fee \npayable on the fee itself.  The fee is only charged on the old balance that is being refinanced. \n4. Debt Interest Payments \nInterest owed is always paid in full at the end of each quarter for the entire life of the debt facility. \n5. Debt Principal Repayments \nDebt is repaid on the last day of each quarter, commencing on the First Debt Repayment Date, \ncontinuing every quarter until the facility is fully repaid.  All debt must be paid off on or before the \nLatest Allowed Debt Maturity Date.  The amount of each repayment must be sculpted so that the \nDSCR is constant for all quarters during the repayment term.  The only exception to this is the final \nrepayment quarter, which can have a higher DSCR.  The repayment amount in any quarter cannot \nexceed the quarterly opening balance of the facility.  Redraws are not permitted. \n6. DSCR \nThe DSCR is defined only for quarters where the principal repayment amount is not zero.  It is equal \neach quarter to the quarterly value of CFADS / (Net Interest Expense + Principal Repayments) \n7. CFADS \nCFADS (Cash Flow Available for Debt Service) is provided by the ‘Operations’ worksheet for each \nquarter.  For clarity, the definition of CFADS does not include any carryover opening balance. \nHint:  Assumptions have been set so that CFADS will be relatively smooth and healthy, and will \nalways be at least as large as Net Interest Expense * Sculpted DSCR \n8. Net Interest Expense \nDefined as: For each quarter, interest owed on Debt plus interest owed on cash account overdraft \nbalance (if any) less interest earned on cash account positive balance (if any).  \n9. Cash Flow Waterfall \nThe Cash Flow Waterfall should include only the following items: \n(1) CFADS; (2) Interest Revenue/(Overdraft Expense) on Cash Balance; (3) Interest Expense \non Debt; (4) Principal Repayments; (5) Equity Distributions \nAll cashflows are assumed to occur on the final day of each quarter. \n10. Equity Distributions \nDistributions occur on the last day of each quarter every June during the Asset life, and at the Asset \nExpiration Date.  All available cash (including the carry over opening balance) is distributed each \ndistribution date, so long as the cash balance is positive immediately prior to distributions. \n11. Equity IRR \nThe Equity IRR should be calculated using the XIRR function, and consider the cashflows to/from \nequity between the Purchase Date and the Asset Expiration Date inclusive. \n \n\nQuestion 5 For Scenario 2, what is the Equity \nIRR ? \n[1 mark] \n [1 mark] \n \n

Interest Calculations \nInterest is calculated on the last day of each quarter as  \n(Opening Balance in Quarter) * (Rate % p.a.) * (Days in Qtr) / 365 \nThis applies to both the interest owed on the Debt, and the interest earned / (owed) on any positive / \n(negative) cash account balance. \n3. Refinancing Calculations \nThe debt is refinanced at three points throughout the term.  The refinanced amount is the outstanding \ndebt balance immediately after principal repayment on the refinancing date. The fee is only charged on the old balance that is being refinanced. \n4. Debt Interest Payments \nInterest owed is always paid in full at the end of each quarter for the entire life of the debt facility. \n5. Debt Principal Repayments \nDebt is repaid on the last day of each quarter, commencing on the First Debt Repayment Date, \ncontinuing every quarter until the facility is fully repaid.  All debt must be paid off on or before the \nLatest Allowed Debt Maturity Date.  The amount of each repayment must be sculpted so that the \nDSCR is constant for all quarters during the repayment term. Net Interest Expense \nDefined as: For each quarter, interest owed on Debt plus interest owed on cash account overdraft \nbalance (if any) less interest earned on cash account positive balance (if any).  \n9. Cash Flow Waterfall \nThe Cash Flow Waterfall should include only the following items: \n(1) CFADS; (2) Interest Revenue/(Overdraft Expense) on Cash Balance; (3) Interest Expense \non Debt; (4) Principal Repayments; (5) Equity Distributions \nAll cashflows are assumed to occur on the final day of each quarter. \n10. Equity Distributions \nDistributions occur on the last day of each quarter every June during the Asset life, and at the Asset \nExpiration Date. Net Interest Expense \nDefined as: For each quarter, interest owed on Debt plus interest owed on cash account overdraft \nbalance (if any) less interest earned on cash account positive balance (if any).  \n9. Cash Flow Waterfall \nThe Cash Flow Waterfall should include only the following items: \n(1) CFADS; (2) Interest Revenue/(Overdraft Expense) on Cash Balance; (3) Interest Expense \non Debt; (4) Principal Repayments; (5) Equity Distributions \nAll cashflows are assumed to occur on the final day of each quarter. \n10. Equity Distributions \nDistributions occur on the last day of each quarter every June during the Asset life, and at the Asset \nExpiration Date.  All available cash (including the carry over opening balance) is distributed each \ndistribution date, so long as the cash balance is positive immediately prior to distributions. \n11. Equity IRR \nThe Equity IRR should be calculated using the XIRR function, and consider the cashflows to/from \nequity between the Purchase Date and the Asset Expiration Date inclusive. \n \n\nQuestion 23 (Free field answer) \nSelect Scenario 10.                                DSBench/data/00000009, INTRODUCTION\nThe provided workbook includes the SOWPODS list of 267,752 English language words (the meaning of \nSOWPODS is not important for the                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         DSBench/data/00000009, INTRODUCTION\nThe provided workbook includes the SOWPODS list of 267,752 English language words (the meaning of \nSOWPODS is not important for the question, but it relates to a popular word-based board game).  This \nList is the source of allowed words for the purpose of this Section. \nTASK \nYour task is to build a model that has the following functions: \nWhen supplied with \ni) An input string of 7 letters (e.g. F I N A N C E) or an input string of 6 letters and a wildcard;\nii) a value for N equal to 5, 6, 7 representing the length of the words; and\niii) a value for X (a positive integer)\nyour model should be able to identify: \n1) How many unique words of length N from the List can be made using the input letters. (For clarity, the \norder of the letters can be rearranged, and each input letter can only be used once per word.  So, if \nFINANCE was the input string and N is 5, INANE (2 N’s) is allowed but FENCE (2 E’s) is not. Also, \ncount INANE once only, not twice.); \n2) For a given value of X, the Xth word in an alphabetical sorted list of the words found in (1); \n3) Which word from those found in (1) scores the highest amount of points when placed in its optimal \nspot on the Board (details on next page).  If more than one word scores the maximum, give the word \nthat would appear first in an alphabetical list of the highest scoring words; and \n4) The score achieved from the optimal placement of the word in (3) above. \n \nASSESSMENT \nAfter 60 minutes of development time, you will be given an answer sheet containing a list of 15 input \nstrings each with its N value and its X value, and space to write your answers.  You will then have an \nadditional 20 minutes to continue work and to find and write down the values for items (1) to (4) above for \neach of the 15 input strings, for a total of 60 answers.  All answers are worth 1 mark each.  An example \nQuestion and its correct answers are provided on the next page to help you self-assess your model. \nTo make the questions more challenging, instead of 7 regular letters, input strings 11 to 15 will contain \n6 letters followed by one wildcard (denoted by a question mark “?”).  The wildcard can be used as any \nof the 26 letters when finding words from the List, and can be used as different letters for different words.  \nFor example, if the input string is “NUMBER?” and N is 5, both RERUN and UNDER are allowed.  In the \nscoring, the wildcard character will have the same points value as the letter it represents.  Also, there is no \ndistinction between RERUN and RERUN.  Count that word once only. \nADDITIONAL RESOURCES AND DEVELOPMENT HINTS \nThe provided workbook includes the worksheet ‘Permutation’ which contains all 5,040 permutations of \nways to list the digits 1 through 7.  You may find this useful. \nDevelopment Hint: Save often, and avoid double-clicking on the fill-handle box (the small square at the \nbottom right of a selected range) in order to apply a formula down a column containing tens of thousands \nof rows.  Doing so has a tendency to freeze Excel.  Use a different method to apply a formula to very large \namounts of cells at once. \n\nSCORING AND THE ‘BOARD’ \nEach letter (A to Z) has been assigned a points value (from 1 to 10), and the wildcard will share the points \nvalue of the letter it represents.  The points per letter can be found on the ‘Scoring’ worksheet of the \nprovided workbook. \nThe Board is a 1 * 13 array of squares, with each square having a multiplier value of 1, 2 or 3.  A word \nmay be placed on the Board with 1 letter per 1 square starting in any position on the Board, provided that: \ni) The placement runs continuously from left to right;\nii) The middle square (#7) is always occupied;\niii) The whole word is placed and final letter does not extend past the end of the Board.\n \nThe ‘Scoring’ worksheet shows an example.  An image of that example is shown.\n \n \nEXAMPLE QUESTION \nThis is the format that each of the 15 cases on the Question and Answer sheet will have, to be provided \nafter 60 minutes of development time.  The underlined values are the answers that you will need to give. \n\nQuestion #    Input string    N (word length)    Value of X\n16 (Example)  FINANCE         6                  3\n\n# of words\n7                              Xth word in list\n                                ENCINA\n\nHighest Scoring Word\nFIANCE                         Highest Score\n                               22\n\nQuestion # Input string N (word length) Value of X \n7 SCANTER 7 4 \n# of words Xth word in list \nHighest Scoring \nWord  Highest Score \n

                                                                        DSBench/data/00000010, INTRODUCTION\nBeing the keen football (soccer) fan that you are, you were excited to learn that in the 2016/17 season \nthere was a football league played between 20 cities of the ancient Byzantine Empire.  The format was a \ndouble round-robin with each team playing all other teams twice, once at home and once away, for a total \nof 38 games per team. \nYou have been provided data for all 380 games.  10 data fields are provided for each game.  They are: \n\nField Name     Description\nDate           The date of the game, given as text in the format yyyymmdd.\nRound          The number of the round (between 1 and 38)\nTeam_H         The name of the home team.\nTeam_A         The name of the away team.\nScore_H        The number of goals scored by the home team.\nScore_A        The number of goals scored by the away team.\nTime_HG        Which minute in the game (between 1 and 95) each home goal was scored. This is given as a single text string with each goal separated by a comma (,).\n               Minute values followed by an asterisk (*) denote that the goal was from a Penalty Kick.\n               If there were no home goals, "---" is the value given.\nTime_AG        Which minute in the game (between 1 and 95) each away goal was scored. Other details are as per the Time_HG field.\nPlayer_HG      The jersey number of the goal scorer (between 1 and 22) of each home goal. This is given as a single text string with each goal separated by a comma (,).\n               The first value corresponds to the first home goal scored, the second value to the second home goal scored, and so on.\n               If there were no home goals, "---" is the value given.\nPlayer_AG      The jersey number of the goal scorer (between 1 and 22) of each away goal. Other details are as per the Player_HG field.\n\n \nThe winner of each game is the team that scores the most goals.  If the score is tied, the game is a draw. \nYour task is to build a model of the league ladder, but this model will need to be flexible to answer all of \nthe questions. Teams \nare ranked on the ladder according to the following criteria, in this order: \n1) Highest number of points \n2) For teams on equal points, rank by highest goal difference (total goals scored less total goals \nconceded) \n3) For teams on equal points and goal difference, rank by highest total goals scored \n4) If two or more teams are still equal after (3), rank those teams equally, but list the equally ranked \nteams in alphabetical order.  (For avoidance of doubt, if M teams are equally ranked in position N, the \nnext best team will have rank N+M, not rank N+1.) \n\nLIST OF TEAMS \nAdrianople\nAni\nAntioch\nBari\nChalcedon\nCherson\nConstantinople\nDyrrachium\nEdessa\nIconium\nKars\nNaissus\nNicaea\nNicomedia\nOhrid\nPrilep\nSamosata\nSardica\nTrebizond\nVarna\n \nThis list of teams is also provided in column B of the worksheet ‘Check_Sum’. \nFor any questions where the answer is one of the teams, give the Team name, and not the team ID \nnumber. \nTHE CHECK_SUM WORKSHEET \nYou should add your own worksheets to the provided data file to perform your calculations and model your \nleague ladder.  Some of the questions will ask you for the value of the Check_Sum of a given ladder.  For \nthese questions, you should link cells D3:D22 and E3:E22 to your calculated ladder, and then submit \nthe value in the green cell at cell F25.  The use of the Check Sum is designed simply to be a way to easily \nassess if all of your ladder ranking positions are correct. \nYou can also use the list of team names from cells B3:B20.  You should not use this Check Sum \nworksheet for anything else, nor make any edits to it except for the yellow cells D3:E22. \nInstructions on how to sort your ladder: \nLike any traditional sporting league, your ladder should be sorted by rank, with rank 1 (the highest placed \nteam) at the top and rank 20 (the lowest placed team) at the bottom. INTRODUCTION\nBeing the keen football (soccer) fan that you are, you were excited to learn that in the 2016/17 season \nthere was a football league played between 20 cities of the ancient Byzantine Empire.  The format was a \ndouble round-robin with each team playing all other teams twice, once at home and once away, for a total \nof 38 games per team. \nYou have been provided data for all 380 games.  10 data fields are provided for each game.  They are: \n\nField Name     Description\nDate           The date of the game, given as text in the format yyyymmdd.\nRound          The number of the round (between 1 and 38)\nTeam_H         The name of the home team.\nTeam_A         The name of the away team.\nScore_H        The number of goals scored by the home team.\nScore_A        The number of goals scored by the away team.\nTime_HG        Which minute in the game (between 1 and 95) each home goal was scored. This is given as a single text string with each goal separated by a comma (,).\n               Minute values followed by an asterisk (*) denote that the goal was from a Penalty Kick.\n               If there were no home goals, "---" is the value given.\nTime_AG        Which minute in the game (between 1 and 95) each away goal was scored. Other details are as per the Time_HG field.\nPlayer_HG      The jersey number of the goal scorer (between 1 and 22) of each home goal. This is given as a single text string with each goal separated by a comma (,).\n               The first value corresponds to the first home goal scored, the second value to the second home goal scored, and so on.\n               If there were no home goals, "---" is the value given.\nPlayer_AG      The jersey number of the goal scorer (between 1 and 22) of each away goal. Other details are as per the Player_HG field.\n\n \nThe winner of each game is the team that scores the most goals.  If the score is tied, the game is a draw. \nYour task is to build a model of the league ladder, but this model will need to be flexible to answer all of \nthe questions.  Read through the questions first to get a sense of what flexibility is required. \nLADDER RULES FOR RANKING TEAMS \nFor each game, teams receive 3 points for a win, 1 point for a draw and 0 points for a loss.  Teams \nare ranked on the ladder according to the following criteria, in this order: \n1) Highest number of points \n2) For teams on equal points, rank by highest goal difference (total goals scored less total goals \nconceded) \n3) For teams on equal points and goal difference, rank by highest total goals scored \n4) If two or more teams are still equal after (3), rank those teams equally, but list the equally ranked \nteams in alphabetical order.  (For avoidance of doubt, if M teams are equally ranked in position N, the \nnext best team will have rank N+M, not rank N+1.) \n\nLIST OF TEAMS \nAdrianople\nAni\nAntioch\nBari\nChalcedon\nCherson\nConstantinople\nDyrrachium\nEdessa\nIconium\nKars\nNaissus\nNicaea\nNicomedia\nOhrid\nPrilep\nSamosata\nSardica\nTrebizond\nVarna\n \nThis list of teams is also provided in column B of the worksheet ‘Check_Sum’. \nFor any questions where the answer is one of the teams, give the Team name, and not the team ID \nnumber. \nTHE CHECK_SUM WORKSHEET \nYou should add your own worksheets to the provided data file to perform your calculations and model your \nleague ladder.  Some of the questions will ask you for the value of the Check_Sum of a given ladder.  For \nthese questions, you should link cells D3:D22 and E3:E22 to your calculated ladder, and then submit \nthe value in the green cell at cell F25.  The use of the Check Sum is designed simply to be a way to easily \nassess if all of your ladder ranking positions are correct. \nYou can also use the list of team names from cells B3:B20.  You should not use this Check Sum \nworksheet for anything else, nor make any edits to it except for the yellow cells D3:E22. \nInstructions on how to sort your ladder: \nLike any traditional sporting league, your ladder should be sorted by rank, with rank 1 (the highest placed \nteam) at the top and rank 20 (the lowest placed team) at the bottom.  If a ladder contains two or more \nteams on equal rank (see point 4 in ‘Ladder Rules for Ranking Teams), equally ranked teams should then \nfurther be sorted alphabetically by team name for display purposes, but still given an equal rank value. \nNote that a different displayed sort order will give a different Check sum value from the intended answer. \n \nQUESTION SUMMARY \nQuestions 1 to 7 are based on the complete data set, with no filtering required. \nQuestions 8 to 19 may require you to compile a ladder assuming that some goals and/or some games \nhave been filtered out of the data. on a role in the organising committee for the 2015 Underwater Football World \nChampionship. Your first task is to help the committee understand the potential total cost of flights for the \nchampionship. As part of this, you will need to build a model to allow you to identify flight details and costs \nfor all domestic flights for each team in the Championship.  \nIn order to calculate the potential cost, you are provided with the following information about the \ntournament:  \n1) The tournament consistent of 24 teams divided into four pools, each containing six teams.                                                                           DSBench/data/00000012, INTRODUCTION\nYou work for a Project Company that has an existing senior debt facility which is due to be refinanced. \nThe company already has an annual financial model covering the period from 1 January 2015 to \n31 December 2039, which has been provided to you.  The model forecasts the project’s cashflows, \nincluding the existing senior debt. Your manager has provided this spreadsheet to you and asked you to \nupdate it to include the upcoming refinancing, and to amend the project’s forecast financial statements to \naccount for this. \n \nPART A \nThe inputs below are provided in the “Inputs” worksheet of the provided model. \nTerms of the refinancing debt are as follows: \n \nThe facility will be drawn in one single drawdown on 31 December 2016. \n \nAn arrangement fee of 2% is payable on the amount drawn. \n \nThe amount drawn will be equal to the sum of: \no \nThe balance of the existing senior debt after the repayment on 31 December 2016 is made and; \no \nThe arrangement fee amount. \n \nThe drawdown will be used to pay the arrangement fee and repay the existing debt. \n \nRepayments will be made at the end of each calendar year, apart from in the final year when the \nrepayment is made on the final repayment date. \n \nThe final repayment date should be 30 June 2036, and the debt should be repaid in full on this \ndate. \n \nThe repayment amount in Year N = Opening Balance at start of year * [Days in year N for which \nrefinancing debt is active] / [Total days from the start of Year N until the debt maturity date \ninclusive]. Repayments start from the 2017 year (i.e. there is no repayment relating to 31 \nDecember 2016). \n \nThe interest rate for the loan is 6% and interest should be calculated on an actual/365 basis. \n \nThe company should account for the debt as follows: \n \nInterest should be expensed through the Profit and Loss accounts as incurred. \n \nThe arrangement fee should be amortized through the Profit and Loss accounts over the life of the \nloan according to the following formula: \no \nAmortization charge in Year N = Fee Charged * [Days in year N for which refinancing debt is \nactive] / [Total number of days across all years for which refinancing debt is active] \n \nOn the Cash Flow Statement, the arrangement fee should be incorporated after the Project \nCashflow line, and it should feed in to the Dividends calculation. \n \nThe project will hold on the balance sheet both the refinancing debt balance, and an asset relating \nto the arrangement fee.\n \nPART B \nYour manager has also asked you to calculate a Debt Service Cover Ratio (“DSCR”) for the refinancing \ndebt to show how much buffer the project has in its cashflows above the amount required to pay the \ninterest and repayments for the refinancing debt. \n \nIn each year that the refinanced loan is active (excluding 2016) this DSCR should be calculated as: \n \nNumerator: \nProject cashflow (as displayed on the Cash Flow Statement) \nApportioned for the number of days in the year that falls within the term of the refinancing debt. \n \nDenominator: \nInterest and Principal Repayments made for the refinancing debt during the year. \n \nYou will also need to calculate a minimum and average DSCR.  The minimum DSCR should be the \nminimum of all the DSCRs over the term of the refinancing debt, and the average DSCR should be the \naverage of all the DSCRs over the term of the refinancing debt.   \n \nYou should answer question 6 before proceeding with the remainder of Part B. \n \nOn seeing the minimum DSCR that the project achieves, your manager tells you that this is higher than \nthe banks require – they are willing to lend money to the project as long as the DSCR remains at or above \n1.80 in each year.  As the DSCR is well above this level, the project could afford to make larger \nrepayments in each period, and therefore the initial drawdown could have been larger. \n \nYour manager wishes to amend the model so that as much debt is borrowed as possible given the \nconstraint that the DSCR cannot ever be below 1.80. Any excess amount drawn over and above the \namount needed to repay the existing senior debt and pay the arrangement fee should be distributed \nimmediately to the shareholders. \n \nTo this end, you have been asked to adjust the drawdown amount and the debt repayments (which may \nnow vary independently in each year) so that in each year a DSCR of exactly 1.80 is achieved and the \ndebt is repaid in full on the final repayment date. \n \nQuestions 1 to 6 relate to Part A. \nQuestions 7 to 10 relate to Part B. \n\nQuestion 1 \nWhat is the amount drawn for the refinancing debt in Part A ?                                                                                                                                                               DSBench/data/00000016, INSTRUCTIONS\nYou are preparing a daily cash flow revenue forecast for a company that has 8 customers (Company A – \nCompany H), all with very specific payment terms. No expense calculations are required. \nThe questions all relate to the 2018 calendar year, but you may need to model before/after this period to \naccurately calculate the cash forecast (calculations should include the relevant days in 2017 and 2019 \nwhere the payment methodology requires it).  \nDo not round your answers at any stage in the model. \nA weekday is defined as a Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday or Friday. A weekend is defined as \nSaturday and Sunday. There are no holidays to consider. \nYou have been provided with an excel workbook file with the ModelOff formatting to use. This file contains \nnone of the inputs provided below – you will need to input these yourself. \n \nCOMPANY A \nCompany A pays a monthly figure of $17.3m. This is paid in 4 segments each month – 11% on day 5, \n21% on day 10, 41% on day 18 and the balance on day 23. Payments are made on the days specified \neven if it is a weekend. \n \nCOMPANY B \nCompany B has a daily charge of $0.35m that accrues daily. The accrued balance is paid monthly on the \nthird Thursday of the month. \nFor example, the payment for January 2018 has accruals from the third Friday in December 2017 until the \nthird Thursday in January 2018 (inclusive). \n \nCOMPANY C \nCompany has a daily charge of $0.18m per day. On weekdays the charge is paid on the same day, on the \nweekends it accrues and is paid on the Monday. \n \nCOMPANY D \nCompany D has a daily charge of $0.23m. This is paid once per month on the 15th. The monthly payment \nis based on the number of days in that calendar month. Payments are made on the day specified even if it \nis a weekend. \n \nCOMPANY E \nThe total monthly charge for Company E is calculated based on the number of Tuesdays in the month at a \nrate of $1.96m per Tuesday. This is paid evenly across all the weekdays of that month. \nRound 2 Section 1 - Case Study Information Pack \n\nCOMPANY F \nCompany F makes 3 payments per month, each of $5.34m. They are paid on the 7th, 14th and 20th of the \nmonth. However, if the payment date is a weekend, it is instead paid on the Friday before the weekend. \n \nCOMPANY G \nCompany G makes a single monthly payment of $9.23m. On even months (February, April etc) it is paid \non the first weekday of the month. On odd months (January, March etc), it is paid on the third weekday of \nthe month. \n \nCOMPANY H \nCompany H makes a payment of $1.79m every Wednesday. However, if the payment falls on the first 10 \ndays of the month it is instead paid 1 day earlier. If the payment falls on the last 10 days of the month, it is \ninstead paid one day later.\n \nFor Questions 1 – 9, 11, select your answer from a multiple choice list. \nFor Questions 10 and 12, you are required to type in your answer.\n\nQuestion 12 Company H is now paid on Tuesdays instead of Wednesdays (with the same adjustments for the first and last 10 days of a month). What is the total cash received in $m from all companies between 1 Jun 2018 and 31 Dec 2018 (inclusive)? Please enter your answer in millions to two decimal places. Use a period “.” as the decimal point character. [4 marks]

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      DSBench/data/00000017, INTRODUCTION\nAll the inputs mentioned below are provided in the workbook for this case study. \nYour company wishes to better understand how its financing cashflows would be affected in times of cash \nshortage. They have asked you to model their two senior debt facilities, two reserve accounts and \nshareholder loan, and then test how the debts are repaid and reserves are funded under different profiles \nof cash generated from operations. \nYour model should be semi-annual with semi-annual periods ending in June and December. All debt \npayments and reserve account transfers occur at the end of a semi-annual period. The model should take \nas its starting point the debt and account balances on 31 December 2017, and should run through to 31 \nDecember 2035. \nQuestions 29 to 34 relate to the target payments and balances and can be answered based on the \ndetails given for the individual facilities and accounts. \nQuestions 35 to 39 relate to the actual payments made under five different profiles of available \ncash, and will require you to have implemented the priority of payments. The cash profiles you are \nrequired to test are increasingly restricted, such that under the first profile everything is fully \nfunded and target balances are met, and under the fifth profile an overdraft is drawn. \nPrepare your model and then use it to answer the given questions. When finished, please upload \nyour workbook (Question 40). \nSENIOR LOANS \nThere are two senior loans. \nSenior 1 \nThe loan balance on 31 December 2017 is $10,000,000.  \nThe loan should be repaid in equal principal repayment amounts with the final repayment occurring in the \nperiod ending 31 December 2023. \nThe interest rates applied to the loan are given in the table below, and interest should be paid as incurred. \nThe annual interest rates should be converted to semi-annual rates by multiplying by the number of days \nthe rate is applied for in the semi-annual period and dividing by 365.\n\n From               To                   Rate (per annum)\n1 January 2018     14 December 2019     4.35%\n15 December 2019   4 April 2021         5.5%\n5 April 2021       24 October 2023      5.8%\n25 October 2023    31 December 2023     6.2%\n\n \nSenior 2 \nThe starting balance for the senior 2 loan is $10,000,000. \nFrom June 2024 onwards principal repayments of $1,000,000 or the outstanding loan amount (whichever \nis smaller) should be made each payment date.\n \nThe interest rate for the Senior 2 loan is 6% per annum. This should be converted to a semi-annual rate \nby dividing by two. Until 31 December 2023 interest incurred should be added to the balance of the loan \n(interest should be incurred on capitalized interest in subsequent semi-annual periods). From 1 January \n2024 onwards interest should be paid as incurred. \nTARGET RESERVE ACCOUNT BALANCES \nThe target debt service reserve account balance is the total senior debt interest and repayments due in \nthe next semi-annual period.  Assume that this account is fully funded on 31 December 2017. \nThe target MMRA balance is 100% of the next twelve months’ major maintenance costs, 66% of the costs \nin the twelve months after that, and 33% of the costs in the twelve months after that. The profile of \nforecast major maintenance costs is given in the Assumptions tab of the provided workbook for this case \nstudy.  Assume that this account is fully funded on 31 December 2017. \nSHAREHOLDER LOAN \nOn 31 December 2017 the shareholder loan balance is $3,000,000. The interest rate for the loan is 9% \nper annum, and this is converted to a semi-annual rate by dividing by two. \nThe target shareholder loan balance is the balance that would result if the loan were an annuity that was \nfully repaid on 31 December 2030 (i.e. if the total interest and repayment amount in each semi-annual \nperiod was constant between June 2018 and December 2030). \nPRIORITY OF PAYMENTS \nIf the balances of the debt service reserve account (DSRA) and major maintenance reserve account \n(MMRA) at the start of the semi-annual period exceed the target balance for the semi-annual period any \nexcess should be added to the cash generated from operations. Available cash should then be used \naccording to the following rules: \n1. The senior interest payments and repayments should always be made. If insufficient cash is \ngenerated from operations to do this, the company does the following in this order until the senior \ndebt payments are made in full: \n• Withdraw money from the debt service reserve account\n• Withdraw money from the major maintenance reserve account\n• Draw an overdraft in the cash account (it is NOT possible to draw an overdraft in the reserve\naccounts). \nAny overdraft drawn should be carried forward from period to period until it is repaid from \navailable cash. Assume that no interest or other costs are incurred related to the overdraft. \nAny available cash left after the senior debt has been serviced should then be used in the following order: \n2. Repay any overdraft drawn in the cash account in previous periods \n3. Fund the MMRA up to the target balance \n4. Fund the DSRA up to the target balance \n5. Pay any interest due on the shareholder loan. Any interest for which there is not enough cash to \npay should be added to the loan balance. \n6. Pay off any outstanding shareholder loan which exceeds the target balance for that semi-annual \nperiod. \nAny cash that is remaining after the debts have been fully serviced and the reserve accounts are fully \nfunded is then paid to the shareholders as a dividend.  \n\nQuestion 29 What is the interest rate for the Senior 1 loan in the period ending 31 December 2019? DSBench/data/00000017, INTRODUCTION\nAll the inputs mentioned below are provided in the workbook for this case study. \nYour company wishes to better understand how its financing cashflows would be affected in times of cash \nshortage. They have asked you to model their two senior debt facilities, two reserve accounts and \nshareholder loan, and then test how the debts are repaid and reserves are funded under different profiles \nof cash generated from operations. \nYour model should be semi-annual with semi-annual periods ending in June and December. All debt \npayments and reserve account transfers occur at the end of a semi-annual period. The model should take \nas its starting point the debt and account balances on 31 December 2017, and should run through to 31 \nDecember 2035. \nQuestions 29 to 34 relate to the target payments and balances and can be answered based on the \ndetails given for the individual facilities and accounts. \nQuestions 35 to 39 relate to the actual payments made under five different profiles of available \ncash, and will require you to have implemented the priority of payments. The cash profiles you are \nrequired to test are increasingly restricted, such that under the first profile everything is fully \nfunded and target balances are met, and under the fifth profile an overdraft is drawn. \nPrepare your model and then use it to answer the given questions. When finished, please upload \nyour workbook (Question 40). \nSENIOR LOANS \nThere are two senior loans. \nSenior 1 \nThe loan balance on 31 December 2017 is $10,000,000.  \nThe loan should be repaid in equal principal repayment amounts with the final repayment occurring in the \nperiod ending 31 December 2023. \nThe interest rates applied to the loan are given in the table below, and interest should be paid as incurred. \nThe annual interest rates should be converted to semi-annual rates by multiplying by the number of days \nthe rate is applied for in the semi-annual period and dividing by 365.\n\n From               To                   Rate (per annum)\n1 January 2018     14 December 2019     4.35%\n15 December 2019   4 April 2021         5.5%\n5 April 2021       24 October 2023      5.8%\n25 October 2023    31 December 2023     6.2%\n\n \nSenior 2 \nThe starting balance for the senior 2 loan is $10,000,000. \nFrom June 2024 onwards principal repayments of $1,000,000 or the outstanding loan amount (whichever \nis smaller) should be made each payment date.\n \nThe interest rate for the Senior 2 loan is 6% per annum. This should be converted to a semi-annual rate \nby dividing by two. Until 31 December 2023 interest incurred should be added to the balance of the loan \n(interest should be incurred on capitalized interest in subsequent semi-annual periods). From 1 January \n2024 onwards interest should be paid as incurred. \nTARGET RESERVE ACCOUNT BALANCES \nThe target debt service reserve account balance is the total senior debt interest and repayments due in \nthe next semi-annual period.  Assume that this account is fully funded on 31 December 2017. \nThe target MMRA balance is 100% of the next twelve months’ major maintenance costs, 66% of the costs \nin the twelve months after that, and 33% of the costs in the twelve months after that. The profile of \nforecast major maintenance costs is given in the Assumptions tab of the provided workbook for this case \nstudy.  Assume that this account is fully funded on 31 December 2017. \nSHAREHOLDER LOAN \nOn 31 December 2017 the shareholder loan balance is $3,000,000. The interest rate for the loan is 9% \nper annum, and this is converted to a semi-annual rate by dividing by two. \nThe target shareholder loan balance is the balance that would result if the loan were an annuity that was \nfully repaid on 31 December 2030 (i.e. if the total interest and repayment amount in each semi-annual \nperiod was constant between June 2018 and December 2030). \nPRIORITY OF PAYMENTS \nIf the balances of the debt service reserve account (DSRA) and major maintenance reserve account \n(MMRA) at the start of the semi-annual period exceed the target balance for the semi-annual period any \nexcess should be added to the cash generated from operations. Assume that no interest or other costs are incurred related to the overdraft. \nAny available cash left after the senior debt has been serviced should then be used in the following order: \n2. Pay any interest due on the shareholder loan. Any interest for which there is not enough cash to \npay should be added to the loan balance. \n6. Pay off any outstanding shareholder loan which exceeds the target balance for that semi-annual \nperiod. \nAny cash that is remaining after the debts have been fully serviced and the reserve accounts are fully \nfunded is then paid to the shareholders as a dividend.  \n\nQuestion 39 Using Profile 5 of cash available from operations, what is the maximum overdraft balance drawn at any point in time? This capital \nexpenditure is real as at 1 January 2017. DSBench/data/00000025, INTRODUCTION\nYou work for a company that wants to forecast its tax obligations and payments over the coming ten \nyears, from 1 January 2016 until 31 December 2025. They have already worked out their forecast taxable \nprofit amount in each month from 1 January 2015 until 31 December 2025, but need you to calculate the \nforecast tax obligations and payments for each relevant period. The company has no trading history in this \ncountry and therefore no tax payments are due from pre-2015 operations. Tax payments will commence \nfrom the 2016 calendar year, based on the taxable profit from the previous calendar year and the \ncompany tax rates and tax rules as set out below. \nThe monthly taxable profit figures and all the inputs below are provided in the workbook for this case \nstudy. \nThe government has announced that the company tax rate will change frequently over the next 10 years \nas follows: \n\nDate start          Date end                   Company tax rate applicable\n1 January 2015      31 March 2015              15%\n1 April 2015        17 May 2016                14%\n18 May 2016         22 September 2016          17%\n23 September 2016   31 March 2019              18%\n1 April 2019        15 August 2020             19%\n16 August 2020      11 November 2020           18%\n12 November 2020    2 February 2021            14%\n3 February 2021     30 June 2021               18%\n1 July 2021         2 February 2022            14%\n3 February 2022     22 February 2022           15%\n23 February 2022    31 March 2024              12%\n1 April 2024        15 May 2025                11%\n16 May 2025         Onwards                    12%\n \nFor months where more than one tax rate is applicable, you should determine an average rate to apply \nweighted by the number of days which the relevant tax rate applies to that month.\n\nThe tax charge in each period is calculated by multiplying the applicable tax rate to the taxable profit \nprofile given in the inputs booklet\n\nThe tax payable is calculated by adjusting the tax charge for losses, which are added a tax loss pool \nwhich works as follows: \n If the tax charge in a month is positive and there are no losses available in the pool, tax payable in\nthat month is equal to the tax charge. \n If the tax charge in a month is positive and there are losses available in the pool, the tax payable\nin the month is the tax charge reduced by the lesser of the amount of the charge and the balance \nof the tax loss pool.  Any losses used in this way must be removed from the tax loss pool. \n If the tax charge in a month is negative it should be added to the tax loss pool and the tax payable\nin that month is zero. \nAssume that the balance in the tax loss pool at the start of the modeled timeline is zero. \nOnce you have calculated the tax payable in each month, you must annualize it to calculate the \ncompany’s tax liability for a year.  The company’s tax year is the calendar year. \nThe annual tax liability is then paid in the subsequent calendar year in the following proportions: \n 60% in April\n 25% in August\n 15% in December\nThe following section is only relevant to questions 39-41. \nThe government is considering a change to tax legislation as follows: \nIf a tax loss is not used within two years after it was created it expires and must be removed from the tax \nloss pool.  For example, if a loss is created in April 2015 and has not been used by the end of April 2017 it \nwill expire at the end of April 2017.  Assume that losses are used and expired in order or age (oldest first). \nYou have been asked to determine what the impact of this would be on the company’s tax payments. \n\nQuestion 32 \nWhat is the tax rate that will be applicable in February 2022 ? #> 248                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         DSBench/data/00000026, INTRODUCTION\nYou have been hired by a consortium to assist with their financial modelling for an upcoming tender.  The \ntender is a government contract to operate and maintain for 15 years an existing asset, a major water \ntreatment facility.  If successful the consortium plans to set up a new company called “OpCo” (short for \nOperating Company) which will carry out the contract.  As part of the tender submission the consortium is \nrequired to bid the amount of revenue it would like OpCo to receive in order to operate and maintain the \nasset. \nYour task is to: \n Model the year 1 expenses in accordance with the data below.\n Model the growth profile of the expenses over the contract life.\n Model the additional Lifecycle Costs (non-recurring one-off expenditure relating to major maintenance\nwork). \n Back solve the necessary bid values for the revenue stream, in order to meet the consortium’s internal\nrevenue sizing conditions. \nYou will probably need to build a simple Cash Flow statement of OpCo in order to complete this task. \nInformation is provided below regarding the assumed expenses of OpCo, the escalation assumptions for \nboth revenues and expenses, as well as general model assumptions.  Use your model to answer the case \nstudy questions. \n \nASSUMPTIONS \nGeneral Model Assumptions \n Your model should be a quarterly model spanning 15 calendar years, from 1 January 2016 to 31\nDecember 2030. \n Unless otherwise specified, assume all book entries and cashflows occur on the final day of the\nquarter. \n \nRevenues \n Revenues are based on two bid values called Base Payment 1 (“BP1”) and Base Payment 2 (“BP2”)\n BP1 and BP2 are annual amounts, expressed in real January 2016 dollars.\n Revenue payments are made every quarter.  The amount paid each quarter end date is equal to\n \nPayment each quarter = (BP1 * 0.25 * IF1) + (BP2 * 0.25 * IF2) \n IF1 and IF2 refer to Indexation Factor 1 and Indexation Factor 2 (see below).\n\nExpenses \n Expenses are categorised in four types:\no Labour, which escalates at Indexation Factor 3 (“IF3”)\no Materials, which escalates at Indexation Factor 4 (“IF4”)\no Other Expenses, which escalates at Indexation Factor 5 (“IF5”)\no Profit Margin, which is sized as a set percentage of the total of the other three expense\ncategories.  This represents a regular and required payment to OpCo’s parent companies. \n Labour Expenses per quarter are $2,500,000 * IF3\n Materials Expenses per quarter are $1,750,000 * IF4\n Other Expenses per quarter are $750,000 * IF5\n Profit Margin Expenses each quarter are 9.00% of the total of Labour, Materials and Other Expenses.\n \nLifecycle Costs \n On 31 December 2021, lifecycle costs of $10,000,000 are incurred (no further escalation needs to be\napplied to this amount). \n On 30 June 2028, lifecycle costs of $5,000,000 are incurred (no further escalation needs to be applied\nto this amount). \n Assume these amounts are fully expensed at the time they are incurred, and are not depreciated.  No\nprofit margin is earned on the Lifecycle Costs. \n \nEscalation and Indexation \n IF1 is equal to 1.00 at 1 Jan 2016, and increases by 2.2% every subsequent 1 January.\n IF2 is equal to 1.00 at 1 Jan 2016, and increases by 4.0% every subsequent 1 January.\n IF3 is equal to 1.00 at 1 Jan 2016, and increases by 4.8% every 1 July\n IF4 is equal to 1.00 at 1 Jan 2016, and increases by 2.5% every subsequent 1 January\n IF5 is equal to 1.00 at 1 Jan 2016, and increases by 2.0% every 1 July\n \nDebt \n All of OpCo’s Expenses and Lifecycle Costs are paid for by cash at the end of each quarter, after\nreceiving the Revenue Payments for that quarter. \n If required, OpCo has access to a short term revolving debt facility.  Any cash shortfall after paying\nexpenses and lifecycle costs is borrowed from the facility at the end of each quarter.  Any excess cash \nremaining after paying expenses and lifecycle costs is applied towards any outstanding balance of the \ndebt facility.   \n When the facility is drawn, interest is charged each quarter at a rate of 3% per quarter of the quarter’s\nopening balance. \n\nCash Float \n At the beginning of the contract, OpCo starts with a cash balance of $5,000,000, provided by its\nparent companies as operating cash.  At the end of the 15 year contract, OpCo is required to return \n$5,000,000 to its parent companies. \n \nOther Considerations \n Assume that all taxes are zero.\n Assume that no interest is earned on OpCo’s positive cash account balance.\n \nRevenue Sizing Conditions \n Values for BP1 and BP2 should be set so that the forecast cash balance on 31 Dec 2030 is exactly\nzero after paying expenses, returning the cash float and paying any outstanding debt balance. \n Neither BP1 nor BP2 can be negative (one of them can, in theory, be zero though)\n \nIn addition to the two conditions above (which should be adhered to for all questions), the following \nadditional Revenue Sizing conditions apply to specific questions as indicated: \n For Questions 27 to 29, Revenue sizing is not needed.\n For Questions 30 to 31, follow the requirements given in the question.\n For Questions 32 to 35, BP1 must be an integer multiple of $500,000.\n For Questions 32 to 37, BP1 and BP2 should be sized so that the term “ADS” is minimized.\no “ADS” stands for Absolute Difference Sum and is equal to the sum over all quarters of D\no D, for any given quarter, is equal to the absolute value of:\n Revenues – Expenses – Lifecycle Costs\n\nThere is no workbook provided for this section.  You will need to create your own.\n\n\n\nQuestion 1 \nWhat are the total Labour Expenses in calendar year 2019? [2 marks] \na. $11,786,466  \nb. $11,786,471 \nc. $11,786,476 \nd. $11,786,481 \ne. $11,786,486 \nf. $11,786,491
