Use your model to answer the case \nstudy questions. \n \nASSUMPTIONS \nGeneral Model Assumptions \n Your model should be a quarterly model spanning 15 calendar years, from 1 January 2016 to 31\nDecember 2030. \n Unless otherwise specified, assume all book entries and cashflows occur on the final day of the\nquarter. \n \nRevenues \n Revenues are based on two bid values called Base Payment 1 (“BP1”) and Base Payment 2 (“BP2”)\n BP1 and BP2 are annual amounts, expressed in real January 2016 dollars.\n Revenue payments are made every quarter.  The amount paid each quarter end date is equal to\n \nPayment each quarter = (BP1 * 0.25 * IF1) + (BP2 * 0.25 * IF2) \n IF1 and IF2 refer to Indexation Factor 1 and Indexation Factor 2 (see below).\n\nExpenses \n Expenses are categorised in four types:\no Labour, which escalates at Indexation Factor 3 (“IF3”)\no Materials, which escalates at Indexation Factor 4 (“IF4”)\no Other Expenses, which escalates at Indexation Factor 5 (“IF5”)\no Profit Margin, which is sized as a set percentage of the total of the other three expense\ncategories.  This represents a regular and required payment to OpCo’s parent companies. \n Labour Expenses per quarter are $2,500,000 * IF3\n Materials Expenses per quarter are $1,750,000 * IF4\n Other Expenses per quarter are $750,000 * IF5\n Profit Margin Expenses each quarter are 9.00% of the total of Labour, Materials and Other Expenses.\n \nLifecycle Costs \n On 31 December 2021, lifecycle costs of $10,000,000 are incurred (no further escalation needs to be\napplied to this amount). \n On 30 June 2028, lifecycle costs of $5,000,000 are incurred (no further escalation needs to be applied\nto this amount). \n Assume these amounts are fully expensed at the time they are incurred, and are not depreciated.  No\nprofit margin is earned on the Lifecycle Costs. \n \nEscalation and Indexation \n IF1 is equal to 1.00 at 1 Jan 2016, and increases by 2.2% every subsequent 1 January.\n IF2 is equal to 1.00 at 1 Jan 2016, and increases by 4.0% every subsequent 1 January.\n IF3 is equal to 1.00 at 1 Jan 2016, and increases by 4.8% every 1 July\n IF4 is equal to 1.00 at 1 Jan 2016, and increases by 2.5% every subsequent 1 January\n IF5 is equal to 1.00 at 1 Jan 2016, and increases by 2.0% every 1 July\n \nDebt \n All of OpCo’s Expenses and Lifecycle Costs are paid for by cash at the end of each quarter, after\nreceiving the Revenue Payments for that quarter. \n If required, OpCo has access to a short term revolving debt facility.  Any cash shortfall after paying\nexpenses and lifecycle costs is borrowed from the facility at the end of each quarter.  Any excess cash \nremaining after paying expenses and lifecycle costs is applied towards any outstanding balance of the \ndebt facility.   \n When the facility is drawn, interest is charged each quarter at a rate of 3% per quarter of the quarter’s\nopening balance. \n\nCash Float \n At the beginning of the contract, OpCo starts with a cash balance of $5,000,000, provided by its\nparent companies as operating cash.  At the end of the 15 year contract, OpCo is required to return \n$5,000,000 to its parent companies. \n \nOther Considerations \n Assume that all taxes are zero.\n Assume that no interest is earned on OpCo’s positive cash account balance.\n \nRevenue Sizing Conditions \n Values for BP1 and BP2 should be set so that the forecast cash balance on 31 Dec 2030 is exactly\nzero after paying expenses, returning the cash float and paying any outstanding debt balance. \n Neither BP1 nor BP2 can be negative (one of them can, in theory, be zero though)\n \nIn addition to the two conditions above (which should be adhered to for all questions), the following \nadditional Revenue Sizing conditions apply to specific questions as indicated: \n For Questions 27 to 29, Revenue sizing is not needed.\n For Questions 30 to 31, follow the requirements given in the question.\n For Questions 32 to 35, BP1 must be an integer multiple of $500,000.\n For Questions 32 to 37, BP1 and BP2 should be sized so that the term “ADS” is minimized.\no “ADS” stands for Absolute Difference Sum and is equal to the sum over all quarters of D\no D, for any given quarter, is equal to the absolute value of:\n Revenues – Expenses – Lifecycle Costs\n\nThere is no workbook provided for this section.  You will need to create your own.\n\n\n\nQuestion 11 \nThis question uses the same assumptions and conditions as the previous question. \nRound BP1 to the nearest whole dollar, and you will have a number that is either 6, 7 or 8 digits\nlong. DSBench/data/00000027, INTRODUCTION\nYou are in the final stages of applying for a job as an analyst at a small private equity firm.  The help \nassess your skills, the firm asks you to complete what it calls its “Bread and Butter” test – an example of \nthe fundamental model building work that its analysts need to do day in and day out.   You will need to \nbuild a dynamic financial model showing the forecast performance of a fictitious technology company they \nare looking to purchase, Macrohard. \nThe firm would like a “3-way integrated financial model” – that is a model which includes the 3 standard \nfinancial statements (Profit and Loss, Balance Sheet, Cash Flow Statement) and allows updates to \nassumption values to correctly flow through to all of the financial statements.  In order to model the \nstatements correctly you will also need to do some simple modelling of a debt facility and depreciation \ntranches.  The final output of the model will be the distributions to equity investors and the IRR achieved \nby the equity investors. \nInformation is provided below regarding the assumed forecast performance of Macrohard as well as \ngeneral model assumptions.  Use your model to answer the case study questions. \nTo assist you, a workbook has been provided that includes some of the assumptions you will need, plus a \ntemplate for the Balance Sheet, and Profit and Loss Statement.  No template is provided for the Cash \nFlow Statement. \n \nASSUMPTIONS \nGeneral Model Assumptions \n Your model should be an annual model showing 10 calendar year time periods, plus the initial “Day 0”\nBalance Sheet. \n The equity investment date (“Day 0”) is 31 December 2015.\n The first period (“Year 1”) covers 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2016, and the final model period\n(“Year 10”) covers 1 January 2025 to 31 December 2025. Any activity after year 10 is ignored for \nanalysis purposes and is not modelled. \n Unless otherwise specified, assume all cashflows occur on the final day of the period.\n\nDay 0 Transactions / Initial Investment \n $30,000,000 equity is invested on Day 0.\n $20,000,000 debt is borrowed on Day 0.\n The Balance Sheet Assets on Day 0 are:\n    o $3,000,000 cash\n    o $3,000,000 accounts receivable\n    o $4,000,000 inventory\n    o $40,000,000 Property Plant and Equipment (“PPE”)\n \nRevenues \n Year 1 Sales are $25,000,000.\n Sales grow annually by the minimum of either (i) $3,000,000 or (ii) 8% of the previous year’s sales.\n \nCost of Goods Sold \n Cost of Goods Sold equals 60% of sales\n \nExpenses \n Year 1 Expenses are $3,000,000\n Expenses grow annually by 7% of the previous year’s expenses.\n \nCapital Expenditure \n On the final day of Year 4, additional PPE is purchased for $10,000,000.\n This new purchase is 90% funded by an equity injection on the same day, with the remainder funded\nby cash on hand. \n \nDepreciation \n The original $40,000,000 PPE (purchased on Day 0) depreciates over 10 years in a straight line\nmethod ($4,000,000 per year). \n The new PPE (purchased at the end of year 4) depreciates over 5 years in a straight line method.\n \nDebt \n Interest is charged on the outstanding debt at a rate of 6.50% per annum.  Interest is paid at the end\nof each year. \n Principal repayments (i.e. not counting interest) are $2,500,000 per year until the debt is repaid.\nRepayments are made at the end of each year, immediately after interest payments are made.\n \nPayment Terms / Working Capital \n Inventory at the end of each year is equal to 30% of Cost of Goods Sold\n Accounts Receivable at the end of each year are 10% of Sales\n Accounts Payable at the end of each year are 12% of Cost of Goods Sold plus 15% of Expenses\n \nDistributions to Equity \n At the end of each of year, any amount above $4,000,000 in the cash account after all other\nconsiderations are dealt with is distributed to equity investors.  If there is less than or equal to \n$4,000,000 in the cash account prior to distributions, no distribution is made that year.  Sizing of \ndistributions is only constrained by cash available - not by book profits. \n \nOther Considerations \n Assume that all taxes are zero.\n Assume that no interest is earned / paid on Macrohard’s positive / negative cash account balance.\n\nQuestion 1 \nTo the nearest thousand dollars, w hat is the value of Sales in Year 3 ? DSBench/data/00000030, INTRODUCTION\nNote: This question should be read along with the accompanying workbook \nYou work in the business development team of ETech, a technology company that primarily operates out \nof Europe and prepares its financial statements in Euros.   \nETech has a comprehensive corporate model that you use to analyse the impact of any potential \nacquisitions. The corporate model is prepared in Euros on a nominal basis therefore any acquisition \nanalysis needs to be converted to nominal Euros to correctly interface with the corporate model.  \nETech has been approached by JL Goodward, a well-known investment banking firm on behalf of their \nclient GEE, a conglomerate. GEE is looking to divest its technology division and has put a sale process in \nplace. Your mangers and board of directors are excited by the prospect of acquiring GEE’s technology \ndivision and have requested entry into the sales process. \nWith all the legal formalities out of the way, JL Goodward sends you an Information Memorandum (‘IM’) to \nassist you with preparing your Indicative Bid. In the IM you have been provided with management’s \nforecast performance of the business.  \nThe forecast includes sales, opex and capex in real US$ and the opening balance of the two classes of \ntax assets in US$.  You are instructed to ignore all other assets and liabilities for the purpose of preparing \nyour Indicative Bid. Furthermore you are instructed to make the following assumptions: \n    • GEE’s effective tax rate is 40%. Tax is calculated on the last day of the year and paid\n    immediately. Corporate tax will continue to be payable within the US.\n    • That all cash flows (Sales, Opex, Capex etc) happen on the last day of the year.\n    • Depreciation for Tax and Accounting is done using:\n        o For Class A assets, the double declining balance method over 5 years.\n        o For Class B assets, the straight line method over 4 years. Assume the opening balance\nhas not yet been depreciated and will be depreciated over 4 years starting in 2015. \nIn order to prepare your bid, you have talked to your tax advisors, investment committee and ETech’s \nmanagement. Based on these discussions, you have settled on the following assumptions relevant to your \nvaluation: \n    • There are no cross border implications from the acquisition;\n    • You will discount pre financing, post-tax nominal US$ cash flows using a 10% rate in order to\nvalue the assets as at 31 December 2014; \n    • The spot exchange rate as at the valuation date will be 1.31 US$ per 1 Euro;\n    • You are provided with a real US$:Euro exchange rate and told that it has been calculated as a\nnotional exchange rate that can be used to convert directly between real US$ and real Euro. \nHint: Do not use these rates to directly convert between nominal US$ and nominal Euro. \n    • You have formed a view on inflation for both the US$ and Euro, included in the provided\nworkbook. \n \n \n\nQuestion 1 What is the nominal US$:Euro exchange rate in year 7?  a. 1.297 b. 1.308 c. 1.312 d. 1.324

INTRODUCTION\n \nJust over a year ago you had a smart electricity meter installed at your home. This particular model of \nsmart meter reports your usage to your electricity provider every hour. Your electricity contract is due for \nrenewal and being a top financial analyst you decide to identify which contract will minimise your annual \nelectricity cost. \nThere are 3 different types of electricity contracts available to you. Each are described in the table below: \n\nPlan          Explanations\nNo Flex       The cost per kWh of electricity is constant for the entire year\nMonthly Flex  The cost per kWh of electricity fluctuates depending on the month\nHourly Flex   The cost per kWh of electricity fluctuates based on the time of day\n\n \nTo decide which contract is optimal, you decide to compare the costs under each of the contracts \nassuming your usage remains exactly the same as last year. You've contacted your current electricity \nsupplier to obtain your electricity usage history for the last year. Unfortunately they provided it to you in a \npoorly structured and unsorted format, so you will need to clean it up prior to doing your analysis. In the \ndata the hour field identifies when the hour starts, so 8AM would be from 8:00AM until 8:59AM. \n \nSUPPORTING DATA \n \nYou’ve placed your usage history and the specifics of each of the electricity contracts into the supplied \nworkbook. Your usage history is located on the “Usage” sheet while the specifics about each of the \nelectricity contracts is located on the “Contracts” sheet. \n\n\nQuestion 1 What is your average hourly electricity usage?  a. 0.641kWh b. 0.782kWh c. 0.884kWh d. 0.937kWh

                                                                                                                                 DSBench/data/00000033, INTRODUCTION\n \nYou work at a bank and have been asked to prepare a spreadsheet that can generate loan schedules for \npersonal loans taken out by the bank’s customers. The loan details are as follows: \n    • The loan duration can be for any number of months up to 72 months.\n    • Drawdowns occur as a single drawdown for the full balance at the beginning of the loan.\n    • The drawdown can occur on any Business Day. A Business Day is defined as a weekday\n    (Monday to Friday) that is not a Holiday. The list of Holidays has been provided to you.\n    • The Actual Payment Date shall be based on the Regular Payment Date, but adjusted to be a\n    Business Day as described below.\n    • Loan payments are made monthly in arrears, on the Actual Payment Date each month, with the\n    first payment one month after drawdown.\n    • The Regular Payment Date each month will be the same DAY of the month as the loan drawdown\n    (for example, if the drawdown was the 8th of October, then the Regular Payment Date will be the\n    8th of each month).\n    • The Actual Payment Date will equal the Regular Payment Date, subject to the following three\n    conditions:\n \nHINT: For Questions 1-4, you can ignore conditions 2 and 3, as they will not be relevant. \n \nCondition 1:  If the Regular Payment Date is not a Business Day, then the Actual Payment \nDate will be made on the first Business Day after the regular payment date, \nexcept where that Business Day would be in a new calendar month. \n \nHINT: For Questions 5-8, your model will need to also incorporate conditions 2 and 3. \n \nCondition 2: \nIf Condition 1 results in a new calendar month, the Actual Payment Date shall be \nthe last Business Day of the calendar month (which, by definition, will be before \nthe Regular Payment Date) \nCondition 3: \nIf the Regular Payment Date is the 29th, 30th or 31st of the month then, where a \nmonth has fewer days (e.g. February), the Actual Payment Date will be the last \nBusiness Day of the calendar month. \n \n• The Monthly Payment Amount shall be the same for each period, and include both an interest\nportion and a principal portion. Therefore, the split between interest and principal will change from \nperiod to period. \n• Interest due shall be calculated on an Actual / 365 basis based on the number of days between\nsuccessive Actual Payment Dates. \n• Do not round any of your calculations.\n \nYour manager has also given you the following advice for preparing your model: \n• It is expected you will need to use Excel’s Goal Seek tool or equivalent functionality in order to\nfind the Monthly Payment Amount.  Due to the interest periods having a different number of days \nfrom month to month, you will not be able to solve this problem with the PMT, PPMT or IPMT \nfunctions.\n\nHOLIDAY SCHEDULE \n \nYour model should accommodate the following fixed schedule of holidays. \n \nA list of these Holidays is included in the provided workbook. \n \n3 April 2015 \n6 April 2015 \n25 October 2015 \n25 March 2016 \n28 March 2016 \n24 October 2016 \n14 April 2017 \n17 April 2017 \n30 October 2017 \n30 March 2018 \n2 April 2018 \n19 October 2018 \n19 April 2019 \n22 April 2019 \n14 October 2019 \n10 April 2020 \n13 April 2020 \n19 October 2020 \n \nHINT: It may be convenient to construct a static list next to the Holiday List, either through \nformulas or manual entry, of the Actual Payment Date that corresponds to each Holiday. \n \nQuestions 1-4 relate to Loan 1 with the following terms: \nLoan amount: $250,000 \nLoan duration: 72 months \nDrawdown date: 19 January 2015 \nInterest Rate: 5.20% per annum \n \nQuestions 5-8 relate to Loan 2 with the following terms: \nLoan amount: $100,000 \nLoan duration: 48 months \nDrawdown date: 30 June 2015 \nInterest Rate: 7.00% per annum\n\nQuestion 1 For Loan 1, how many of the 72 Regular Payment Dates are not Business Days?  a. 18 b. 21 c. 24 d. 27

DSBench/data/00000038, INTRODUCTION\nYou’ve been asked to prepare a model to forecast the performance of a Solar PV (photo-voltaic) business. \nThe business buys rooftop solar panels from overseas and installs them on the rooftops of people’s \nhouses in Australia. The business then sells the electricity generated at an agreed price schedule to either \nthe owner of the house or the main electrical grid. \n \nYou will need to calculate forecasts of: \ni) kW of installed capacity\nii) Generation of electricity (in kWh)\niii) Purchasing and installation costs\niv) Revenues from generation.\n \nNote on Energy Industry Terminology: \n“kW” stands for kilowatt, and is a measure of electrical power. \n“kWh” stands for kilowatt-hour, and is a measure of energy, equal to the work done by a power of 1 kW for \none hour. \nFor example, a small electric heater might operate at a power of 2,000 watts or 2kW. In three hours of \noperation, it would consume 2kW x 3 hours = 6kWh of electricity (energy). \n \nAs the business is based in Australia, the costs and revenue forecasts need to be prepared in Australian \nDollars (AUD). \n \nYou are to prepare a monthly forecast model that includes the dates from 1 July 2013 to 30 June 2023. \n \nTo assist you in your task, the assumptions page has already been set out for you in the included \nworkbook, but with the operational assumptions missing. You will need to fill in the assumptions, \nand then model the necessary calculations. \n \nOPERATIONAL DETAILS \nPurchasing and installation costs \nThe solar panels are purchased in US Dollars (USD) either as small or large systems. \n \nThe small systems cost US$5,000 and have a rated capacity of 3kW. \nThe large systems cost US$8,000 and have a rated capacity of 5kW. \n \nIn addition to the purchase cost, each system also costs 500 Australian Dollars (AU$500) to install on a \nrooftop. \n \nAssume that costs do not escalate with time. \n \n\nPerformance of panels \nWhen they are new, the panels are forecast to generate 4 kWh of electricity per day per kW of rated \ncapacity.  So for example, a new 3kW system would, in the month of May, generate 4kWh/kW/day * 3kW * \n31 days = 372 kWh of electricity in the month of May. \n \nThe panels degrade over time. When they are brand new (that is, in the month of installation) they operate \nat 100% efficiency. They then decline in efficiency on a diminishing value basis by a constant percentage \namount every month, so that on any given day, the efficiency in 12 months’ time of a panel will be exactly \n99% of its current efficiency. \n \nAssume that the degradation of each panel occurs monthly, instantaneously on the first day of each \nmonth, beginning in the month after installation of that panel. You will need to determine the appropriate \nmonthly degradation rate. \n \nRevenues \nSome of the electricity generated by the panels will be purchased by the house at a price equal to Tariff \nA. The remainder of the electricity generated will be sold to the main electrical grid at a price equal to \nTariff B. \n \nHouses with a small system will purchase 10 kWh of electricity per day from the company at a price equal \nto Tariff A. \nHouses with a large system will purchase 15 kWh of electricity per day from the company at a price equal \nto Tariff A. \n \nPrices \nTariff A: Initial price is AUD $0.2500 per kWh. Each 1 July, beginning on 1 July 2014, the price of Tariff A \nwill escalate by 2%. \n \nTariff B: Initial price is AUD $0.08 per kWh. This tariff does not escalate. \n \nInstallation Details \nThe installation period lasts from July 2013 to June 2015. The number of small and large systems installed \neach month has been provided for you in the included workbook. \n \nAssume that all systems are installed on the first day of the month and begin generation instantly. Assume \nthat the purchasing and installation costs are incurred in the month of installation. \n \nExchange Rate Details \nThe AUD to USD exchange rate for each month during the installation period has also been provided in \nthe included workbook. \n \n \n \n \n \n\nQUESTION 1 What is the total cumulative rated capacity of all installed systems as at 15 September 2014? Pick the closest answer.  a. 4,000 kW b. 5,000 kW c. 5,500 kW d. 6,000 kW

Saratoga for US$1,600,000 and rent it out to take advantage of \nSan Francisco’s thriving rental market! \nIncome and Expense  \nAs a result of the investment going into the area, you hope to sell the apartment in the next 10 years for \ndouble what you paid for it. For the purposes of this model, assume that the property value will grow at a \nconstant % per annum with growth compounding. Further assumptions are as follows: \n Rental income is estimated to be $83,200 per annum\n Agency fees will be 9% of rent per annum\n Rental income will increase annually by 2% in the first two years and by 5% thereafter.\nYou also estimate you will have to spend at least 5% of rental income per annum maintaining the property, \nand you have set a budget of $10,000 to furnish the apartment prior to renting it. \nBorrowing \nABC bank has offered you a 25 year mortgage with:  \n A fixed interest rate of 5% on the outstanding principle for the duration of the loan.\n A bank charge of a $10,000 arrangement fee.\n A maximum loan of $900,000\nThe loan allows early repayment of principal and you intend to use all free cash flow to pay down principal \nat the end of each year. You will contribute the remaining funds required to complete the purchase. \nTax  \n Rental income is taxable\n Interest expense, letting agent fees and maintenance expenses are all tax deductible.\n Assume a tax rate of 35% for your analysis and that tax is paid promptly at year end.\nWhen you sell the property, capital gains tax will be payable. To calculate your capital gain on sale, \ncompare your total purchase price (which will include the house purchase price, mortgage fees, and \nfurniture cost) to the sale price. The difference is the capital gain on the property. Assume a capital gains \ntax rate of 20%. \nThe Model \nYou have decided to build a financial model of this situation for number of reasons. Firstly, the bank has \noffered you the mortgage based on the condition that you provide them with a yearly rental income cash \nflow forecast. They want to ensure that the apartment will generate enough rental income to comfortably \nservice the mortgage.  \nYou also want to use the financial model to calculate the estimated return on your investment and to \ncalculate the best time to exit your investment to maximise your IRR. \n \n\nQuestion 1  What is the Cash Flow Available for Debt Service at the end of the first year?   a. 17,259    b. 18,992   c. 19,211   d. 19,396

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   DSBench/data/00000041, INTRODUCTION\nYou have decided to buy an apartment in Saratoga for US$1,600,000 and rent it out to take advantage of \nSan Francisco’s thriving rental market! \nIncome and Expense  \nAs a result of the investment going into the area, you hope to sell the apartment in the next 10 years for \ndouble what you paid for it. For the purposes of this model, assume that the property value will grow at a \nconstant % per annum with growth compounding. Further assumptions are as follows: \n Rental income is estimated to be $83,200 per annum\n Agency fees will be 9% of rent per annum\n Rental income will increase annually by 2% in the first two years and by 5% thereafter.\nYou also estimate you will have to spend at least 5% of rental income per annum maintaining the property, \nand you have set a budget of $10,000 to furnish the apartment prior to renting it. \nBorrowing \nABC bank has offered you a 25 year mortgage with:  \n A fixed interest rate of 5% on the outstanding principle for the duration of the loan.\n A bank charge of a $10,000 arrangement fee.\n A maximum loan of $900,000\nThe loan allows early repayment of principal and you intend to use all free cash flow to pay down principal \nat the end of each year. You will contribute the remaining funds required to complete the purchase. \nTax  \n Rental income is taxable\n Interest expense, letting agent fees and maintenance expenses are all tax deductible.\n Assume a tax rate of 35% for your analysis and that tax is paid promptly at year end.\nWhen you sell the property, capital gains tax will be payable. To calculate your capital gain on sale, \ncompare your total purchase price (which will include the house purchase price, mortgage fees, and \nfurniture cost) to the sale price. The difference is the capital gain on the property. Assume a capital gains \ntax rate of 20%. \nThe Model \nYou have decided to build a financial model of this situation for number of reasons. Firstly, the bank has \noffered you the mortgage based on the condition that you provide them with a yearly rental income cash \nflow forecast. They want to ensure that the apartment will generate enough rental income to comfortably \nservice the mortgage.  \nYou also want to use the financial model to calculate the estimated return on your investment and to \ncalculate the best time to exit your investment to maximise your IRR. \n \n\nQuestion 5   The highest IRR achieved is by exiting in which year?  a. Year 2    b. Year 5    c. Year 6    d. Year 8
